title: Ben Folds on His Orchestral Album, Leaving the Kennedy Center, and the Mission to Keep Art Alive: Podcast
description: The singer-songwriter flipped Trump the bird with a 4th of July release. Ben Folds on His Orchestral Album, Leaving the Kennedy Center, and the Mission to Keep Art Alive: Podcast Kyle Meredith
author: Kyle Meredith
excerpt: Ben Folds joins the Kyle Meredith With podcast to discuss his new live orchestral album, leaving the Kennedy Center, and keeping art alive.
text: Listen via: Apple Podcasts | Spotify | Amazon Podcasts | More Platforms Ben Folds recently sat down with Kyle Meredith to talk about the complicated year that saw him record a stunning live album with the National Symphony Orchestra just before stepping down as Artistic Advisor for the Kennedy Center. Folds opens up about the importance of the Kennedy Center’s mission, how it connects communities beyond the stage, and why that made his exit during the Trump administration’s takeover so necessary. Listen above or wherever you get your podcasts. Reflecting on the album, Folds calls it “an absolute honor” to record with the NSO, praising the room’s natural magic and the delicate work of mixer David Boucher. “David’s just next level,” Folds says. “It doesn’t sound like a live record until you hear the clapping — that’s how you know you got it right.” The album arrives like an act of resistance, beginning with “But Wait, There’s More,” which Folds says was born out of the absurdity of the Four Seasons Total Landscaping press conference. “It felt so cynical at first, but I do still believe there’s more good than not,” he adds. The conversation also dives deep into the vital role of public funding and arts institutions, and how Folds’ Kennedy Center series aimed to break down barriers and build trust between artists and audiences. “When you bring in people with something to say, the orchestra becomes part of telling that story,” he explains. “That mission — that trust — that’s what makes it special. When the mission’s broken, it all falls apart.” Folds remains hopeful that the simple act of gathering to experience art together is itself a form of resistance. “Maybe this wakes us up,” he says. “We’re all capable of anything — don’t do the bad stuff.” Listen to Ben Folds discuss Live with The National Symphony Orchestra and more above, or watch the interview below.
